# Cambridge IGCSE™

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
0606/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 302, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 218, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 91]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 136, 554, 155]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 168, 242, 186]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 198, 368, 216]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\),  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 216, 576, 252]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 266, 230, 284]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 286, 737, 327]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 331, 477, 371]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 394, 384, 411]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 413, 522, 444]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 467, 267, 485]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = ar^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 488, 416, 522]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 526, 406, 555]]<|/det|>
\[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 575, 586, 593]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 606, 161, 623]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 621, 572, 672]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 700, 243, 718]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 718, 578, 750]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 758, 584, 778]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 785, 551, 814]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
On the axes below, sketch the graph of \(y = \left|(x - 2)(x + 1)(x + 2)\right|\) showing the coordinates of the points where the curve meets the axes. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 225, 907, 598]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 92, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 593, 101]]<|/det|>
The volume, \(V,\) of a sphere of radius \(r\) is given by \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^{3}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 108, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
The radius, \(r \mathrm{cm}\), of a sphere is increasing at the rate of \(0.5 \mathrm{cm} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\). Find, in terms of \(\pi\), the rate of change of the volume of the sphere when \(r = 0.25\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 96, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 144, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 77, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Find the first 3 terms in the expansion of \(\left(4 - \frac{x}{16}\right)^6\) in ascending powers of \(x\). Give each term in its simplest form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 98, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 144, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 541, 757, 570]]<|/det|>
Hence find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(4 - \frac{x}{16}\right)^6 \left(x - \frac{1}{x}\right)^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 545, 920, 564]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 922, 106]]<|/det|>
Find how many different 5-digit numbers can be formed using the digits 1, 2, 3, 5, 7 and 8, if each digit may be used only once in any number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 715, 183]]<|/det|>
How many of the numbers found in **part (i)** are not divisible by 5?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 256, 181, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 255, 803, 275]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 146, 492]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
The number of combinations of \(n\) items taken 3 at a time is 6 times the number of combinations of \(n\) items taken 2 at a time. Find the value of the constant \(n\).

<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 402, 920, 453]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the straight line \(2x + y = - 5\) and part of the curve \(xy + 3 = 0\). The straight line intersects the \(x\)-axis at the point \(A\) and intersects the curve at the point \(B\). The point \(C\) lies on the curve. The point \(D\) has coordinates \((1, 0)\). The line \(CD\) is parallel to the \(y\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 144, 483]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 464, 551, 483]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 465, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region, giving your answer in the form \(p + \ln q\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are positive integers. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 96, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 143, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 78, 876, 120]]<|/det|>
Given that \(y = \left(x^{2} - 1\right)\sqrt{5x + 2}\), show that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = \frac{Ax^{2} + Bx + C}{2\sqrt{5x + 2}}\), where \(A, B\) and \(C\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 98, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 146, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 920, 114]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary point of the curve \(y = \left(x^{2} - 1\right)\sqrt{5x + 2}\), for \(x > 0\). Give each coordinate correct to 2 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 94, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 653, 144, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 651, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 87, 838, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 900, 435]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a triangle \(OAB\) such that \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\). The point \(P\) lies on \(OA\) such that \(OP = \frac{3}{4} OA\). The point \(Q\) is the mid-point of \(AB\). The lines \(OB\) and \(PQ\) are extended to meet at the point \(R\). Find, in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 445, 146, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 193, 465]]<|/det|>
\(\overrightarrow{AB}\) ,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 447, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 146, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 585, 499, 606]]<|/det|>
\(\overrightarrow{PQ}\). Give your answer in its simplest form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 586, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 767, 96]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(n\overrightarrow{PQ} = \overrightarrow{QR}\) and \(\overrightarrow{BR} = k\mathbf{b}\), where \(n\) and \(k\) are positive constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 108, 144, 127]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 405, 127]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{QR}\) in terms of \(n\), \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 247, 146, 266]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 246, 405, 266]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{QR}\) in terms of \(k\), \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 247, 920, 266]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 432, 144, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 430, 451]]<|/det|>
Hence find the value of \(n\) and of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line such that its displacement, \(x \mathrm{~m}\), from a fixed point \(O\) at time \(t \mathrm{~s}\) is given by \(x = 10 \sin 2t - 5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 180, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 448, 135]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 241, 180, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 241, 544, 259]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 329, 920, 395]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the velocity–time graph for a particle \(Q\) travelling in a straight line with velocity \(v \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) at time \(t \mathrm{s}\). The particle accelerates at \(3.5 \mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\) for the first \(10 \mathrm{s}\) of its motion and then travels at constant velocity, \(V \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\), for \(10 \mathrm{s}\). The particle then decelerates at a constant rate and comes to rest. The distance travelled during the interval \(20 \leqslant t \leqslant 25\) is \(112.5 \mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 407, 180, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 407, 351, 425]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 500, 920, 518]]<|/det|>
